title: New mechanical 12-speed Shimano GRX groupsets bring huge gear range to gravel
content:
Cyclist
New mechanical 12-speed Shimano GRX groupsets bring huge gear range to gravel  

Shimano has updated its GRX gravel groupset family to bring 12-speed cassettes to its mechanical tiers. The new RX820 and RX610 groupsets both include three new drivetrain setups alongside updated ergonomics and improved brakes. Shimano has also released new carbon RX880 gravel wheels too, with interchangeable freehub body options. 

The Japanese giant has given nicknames to each of the three new 12-speed GRX drivetrains that help to explain the riding each one is best suited for. ‘Unbeatable’ is a racy 1× setup with a 10-45t cassette and either a 42t or 40t chainring that has a smaller range but smaller steps between gears. ‘Unstoppable’ is another 1× and has the same chainring options but with a big 10-51t cassette for lots of climbing, and both use Shimano’s Micro Spline freehub standard. ‘Undroppable’ is the 2× all-rounder, with a 48-31t crankset and a choice of 11-34t or 11-36t cassettes  

The 2x cassettes use the HG and HG L2 spline pattern, meaning only the 2× drivetrain is backwards-compatible with existing gravel wheels. The 1× groupsets will rely on hub manufacturers producing a Micro Spline body for their road hubs. At present, outside of Shimano itself only DT Swiss offers one. 

Shimano has also updated the ergonomics of the GRX brake levers and hoods to work better around flared drop bars. 

Full groupset prices are £1,251.95/$1,584.91 USD/$2,263 AUD for the 2× and £1,270.97/$1,542.92 USD/$2,270 AUD with an extra £40 for the option with a dropper post lever. Retaining GRX’s modular capability, the new RX610 cranksets and brake levers that can be subbed into the RX820 groupsets to add a lower price point to the range, with those parts the 2× groupset can be purchased from £1,031.95/$1,233.91 USD/$1,701 AUD and the 1× from £976.96/$1,165.92 USD/$1,654 AUD. For EU prices, customers should visit a Shimano dealer.

Shimano claims weight for the full groupsets start at 2,720.2g for the 1× options.

Finally, a new RX880 carbon gravel wheelset is also included in this launch, which Shimano claims is 64g lighter than its predecessor and includes a new rear hub design that allows riders to switch between Micro Spline and HG L2 freehub bodies. The RX880 wheel prices have yet to be confirmed. 

A 12-speed Shimano 105 mechanical groupset has been released concurrently with the 12-speed GRX – but this mechanical-only update means a 12-speed version of the electronic GRX Di2 groupset is still to come.  

The new components will be available to buy and specced on new bikes from 1st September, in the UK visit freewheel.co.uk

Key details 

  • Three new 12-speed drivetrains at two tiers. 
  • Two 1× for either smaller steps or a bigger range of gears and one 2× for a bit of both. 
  • New RX600-series parts make 12-speed more accessible. 
  • Updated ergonomics on the hoods and brake levers designed for flared bars. 
  • Lighter RX880 carbon gravel wheels that allow riders to switch freehub bodies. 
  • No 12-speed GRX Di2 yet. 

Why mechanical first? 

With most drivetrain developments these days focussing on top-end electronic groupsets or bringing electronic shifting to a more accessible price, it’s somewhat surprising that Shimano has released 12-speed mechanical GRX before electronic GRX Di2 – though that will come in the not-too-distant future. Shimano says that this is because about 75% of its global gravel sales are of mechanical parts. 

Three new drivetrains 

Shimano says it decided to create three drivetrains for the RX820 range – as opposed to just having a choice between 1× and 2× – to reflect that breadth of what ‘gravel’ is and how people are riding – or racing – on gravel differently.  

As mentioned above, those are the close-step ‘Unbeatable’, big range ‘Unstoppable’ and all-rounder ‘Undroppable’. Both 1× options have a 10-tooth sprocket on the cassettes, whereas the smallest was 11-tooth on the RX810 cassettes, and use the Micro Spline freehub body to accommodate that smaller sprocket. The 2× groupset cassettes use the HG L2 spline pattern seen on Shimano’s 12-speed road components, and Shimano says either of the 2× cassettes will work with existing 11-speed HG wheelsets.  

The close-step 1× drivetrain is comprised of either a 42T or 40T chainring with a 10-45t cassette, but what’s actually new is the chainring and rear derailleur. Just as the last generation GRX borrowed from Shimano’s MTB cassettes, this one does too, with the 10-45 cassette coming from the brand’s Deore XT groupset. Shimano says this setup is more suited to racing, with smaller steps between gears than the other two options but a bigger range than the RX810 1× drivetrain. 

The wide-range 1× setup uses the same chainring choice but with the 10-51t Deore XT M8100 cassette option, which creates a drivetrain that gives a much bigger spread of gears for climbing. Shimano says this is the option for longer, climb-heavy adventures. 

The 2× setup is comprised of a 48-31T crankset with either an 11-34t (R8101) or 11-36t (HG710) cassette, essentially the same cassettes Shimano’s Ultregra and 105 tiers now use. This provides both close gearing and wide range. Shimano has also offset the front deraillleur position to add 2.5mm of extra clearance to the rear tyre to account for mud build-up. 

A notable development on the new generation rear derailleurs is their cage designs. They come in RX822-GS, RX822-SGS and RX820 derivations. RX820 is for the 2× groupset, and the difference between GS and SGS RX822 derailleurs is the cage length and position of the pulley (GS accommodates the 10-51 cassette, SGS the 10-45). The cages themselves are detachable, meaning the user just needs to swap cages to accommodate different cassettes rather than switch out the whole derailleur. All three rear derailleurs feature the Shimano Shadow RD+ clutch to reduce chain slap and help keep the chain in place. 

Alongside the RX820 products are a few interchangeable RX610 parts that help bring the new technology down to more accessible prices. That’s RX610 cranksets, which come in either a 38t 1× – which actually can create an even lower gear on the ‘Unstoppable’ drivetrain – or 46-30t 2×, and RX610 brake levers. 

Updated ergonomics 

Shimano has also adapted the brake lever and hood design to increase ergonomics on off-road rides. The most notable aspect of this is that it’s been tailored for flared handlebars as the hoods are tilted when the drops are flared. Shimano says it saw a noticeable decrease in palm pressure on flared bars with the new hoods, which are designed for 12-16° of flare. This isn’t included in the RX610 lever design though. 

This generation also sees the anti-slip brake lever coating – which Shimano actually gets from its fishing department – rolled out to all models as standard, including the RX610 levers, as opposed to only the highest tiers in the groupset family. 

New to GRX brakes  

The RX820 brakes adopt the updates from the latest road calliper designs, meaning increased pad clearance, Servowave braking technology to improve brake feel and power, and a separate bleed port to make maintenance easier. The new CL rotors have also been brought over, which are lighter and said to cope with heat distortion better. 

RX880 wheels 

Shimano has also released new RX880 gravel-specific wheels. They use 32mm deep, hooked carbon fibre rims, with 25mm internal rim widths. The Direct Engagement freehub system seen on Dura-Ace wheels has also been incorporated, this means gears and springs replace the pawl type ratchets, which increases drive rigidity and helps reduce the system weight. There’s Micro Spline and HG freehub versions supplied as standard, and the bodies are interchangeable to accommodate the different cassettes options the new groupset now offers. 11-speed HG cassettes aren’t compatible.  

The RX870 wheels that were released last year are 12-speed compatible and will be kept on in the range.
